expanded_description: When we know two points on a line, we have all the information needed to determine its equation. This situation arises frequently in real-world applications—from experimental data points to historical records. The process involves finding the slope from the two points, then using one of the points to write the equation.

core_concept.principle: Given two points $(x_1, y_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2)$, the equation of the line through them can be found by: (1) Calculating the slope $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$. (2) Using point-slope form $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$ with either point. (3) Simplifying to slope-intercept form $y = mx + b$ if desired.
core_concept.explanation: Think of two points as two fixed locations. The slope tells you the direction and steepness of the path between them. Once you know that, you can extend the line in both directions and write its equation. Any two points determine a unique line—like two pins on a map determining a straight route.

image.alt: Two points on coordinate plane with line through them, slope formula shown
image.caption: Figure 5.3.1: Two points determine a unique line.

sections.introduction: The first step in writing an equation from two points is finding the slope. This is a direct application of the slope formula.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.3.2: Finding slope from two points.

key_concept.definition: The slope of the line through points $(x_1, y_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2)$ is $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$, provided $x_1 \neq x_2$. The order of subtraction must be consistent in numerator and denominator.
key_concept.context: This is the same slope formula we've used before. The key is to be careful with signs, especially when coordinates are negative.

image.alt: Examples of slope calculation with various point pairs
image.caption: Figure 5.3.3: Calculating slope from different point pairs.

worked_examples.title: Finding Slope from Two Points

image.caption: Figure 5.3.4: Find the slope between each pair.

worked_examples.problem:
Find the slope between each pair of points:
a) $(2, 3)$ and $(5, 9)$
b) $(-1, 4)$ and $(3, -4)$
c) $(4, 2)$ and $(4, 7)$
d) $(1, 5)$ and $(6, 5)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope formula works for all cases. Watch for special cases (vertical/horizontal).

image.alt: Summary of finding slope from two points
image.caption: Figure 5.3.5: Finding slope from two points summary.

sections.introduction: Once we have the slope, we can use either of the two points with point-slope form to write the equation.

introduction_image.alt: Using slope and one point to write equation
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.3.6: Using point-slope form with one of the points.

key_concept.definition: After finding slope $m$, choose either point $(x_1, y_1)$ and substitute into $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$. Both points will give the same equation after simplification (though they may look different before simplifying).
key_concept.context: Either point works—choose the one that makes the arithmetic easier, perhaps with simpler numbers or fewer negatives.

image.alt: Step-by-step: find m, then use point-slope
image.caption: Figure 5.3.7: Process for writing equation.

worked_examples.title: Writing Equations from Two Points

image.caption: Figure 5.3.8: Write equation for each pair.

worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line through each pair of points. Leave in slope-intercept form.
a) $(1, 2)$ and $(3, 8)$
b) $(-2, 5)$ and $(2, 1)$
c) $(0, 3)$ and $(4, 5)$
d) $(-3, -1)$ and $(2, 4)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Find slope, then use point-slope with either point, simplify to $y = mx + b$.

process_flow.description: Use $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$ with the two given points.
process_flow.mechanism: Be consistent with subtraction order. Simplify if possible.

process_flow.description: Select either of the two original points to use in point-slope form.
process_flow.mechanism: Choose the point with simpler coordinates if possible.

process_flow.description: Substitute $m$ and $(x_1, y_1)$ into $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$.
process_flow.mechanism: Pay attention to signs, especially with negative coordinates.

process_flow.description: Distribute the slope and solve for $y$.
process_flow.mechanism: Add or subtract constants to isolate $y$.

image.alt: Summary of writing equations from two points
image.caption: Figure 5.3.13: Writing equations from two points summary.

sections.section_title: 5.3.3 Finding Y-Intercept Directly from Two Points
sections.introduction: Another approach is to find the slope, then use the equation $y = mx + b$ with one point to solve for $b$ directly.

introduction_image.alt: Using y = mx + b to find intercept
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.3.14: Finding y-intercept directly.

key_concept.definition: After finding slope $m$, substitute either point $(x_1, y_1)$ into $y = mx + b$ to solve for $b$: $y_1 = m x_1 + b$, so $b = y_1 - m x_1$. Then write $y = mx + b$.
key_concept.context: This method is efficient if you prefer working directly with slope-intercept form and don't want to handle point-slope intermediate steps.

image.alt: Solving for b: b = y₁ - mx₁
image.caption: Figure 5.3.15: Finding b directly.

worked_examples.title: Finding Y-Intercept Directly

image.caption: Figure 5.3.16: Find equation using direct b method.

worked_examples.problem:
For each pair of points, find the equation by first finding slope, then finding $b$ directly.
a) $(2, 5)$ and $(4, 11)$
b) $(-3, 7)$ and $(1, -1)$
c) $(0, 4)$ and $(5, 2)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Find m, then $b = y_1 - m x_1$, then write $y = mx + b$.

image.alt: Summary of finding y-intercept directly from two points
image.caption: Figure 5.3.17: Direct b method summary.

sections.introduction: Points may have fractional coordinates. The process is the same, but requires careful fraction arithmetic.

key_concept.definition: When points have fractional coordinates, find slope using the same formula. You may need to find common denominators to subtract fractions. The resulting equation may have fractional coefficients, which can be left as fractions or converted to decimals.
key_concept.context: Fractional coordinates often arise from real-world measurements that aren't whole numbers. Being comfortable with fraction arithmetic is essential.

worked_examples.title: Equations from Fractional Points

image.caption: Figure 5.3.20: Write equations for these fractional points.

worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line through each pair of points:
a) $(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{4})$ and $(\frac{3}{2}, \frac{7}{4})$
b) $(\frac{2}{3}, \frac{1}{2})$ and $(\frac{5}{3}, 2)$
c) $(-\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{2})$ and $(\frac{3}{4}, \frac{1}{2})$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Fractional coordinates work the same way; use fraction arithmetic carefully.

image.alt: Summary of working with fractional coordinates
image.caption: Figure 5.3.21: Fractional coordinates summary.

sections.section_title: 5.3.5 Special Cases: Horizontal and Vertical Lines
sections.introduction: When the two points have the same y-coordinate or same x-coordinate, the line is horizontal or vertical, respectively.

introduction_image.alt: Points with same y (horizontal) and same x (vertical)
introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.3.22: Special cases from two points.

key_concept.definition: If $y_1 = y_2$, the line is horizontal with equation $y = y_1$. Slope $m = 0$. If $x_1 = x_2$, the line is vertical with equation $x = x_1$. Slope is undefined.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these special cases saves work—you don't need to calculate slope or use point-slope form. Just write the appropriate equation directly.

image.alt: Horizontal and vertical lines from points
image.caption: Figure 5.3.23: Recognizing special cases.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Special Cases

image.caption: Figure 5.3.24: Write equations for these special cases.

worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line through each pair of points:
a) $(2, 5)$ and $(7, 5)$
b) $(-3, 4)$ and $(-3, -2)$
c) $(0, 3)$ and $(5, 3)$
d) $(4, 1)$ and $(4, 8)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Same y → horizontal (y = constant). Same x → vertical (x = constant).

image.alt: Summary of special cases from two points
image.caption: Figure 5.3.25: Special cases summary.

sections.introduction: In real life, we often have two data points and need to find the relationship between variables.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 5.3.26: Two data points in real-world contexts.

key_concept.definition: Given two data points from an experiment, survey, or historical record, we can find the linear equation that models the relationship. This allows us to predict values between or beyond the given points (interpolation and extrapolation).
key_concept.context: Examples: temperature at two times, cost for two quantities, population at two years, distance at two times. Two points give us the line, which models the trend.

image.alt: Graph with two data points and line through them
image.caption: Figure 5.3.27: Modeling with two data points.

worked_examples.title: Temperature Conversion
worked_examples.problem: We know that water freezes at $0°C = 32°F$ and boils at $100°C = 212°F$. Find a linear equation that converts Celsius to Fahrenheit.

step_by_step.explanation: Let C = Celsius, F = Fahrenheit. Points: $(0, 32)$ and $(100, 212)$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Two known points determine the conversion formula.

worked_examples.title: Cost Prediction
worked_examples.problem: A printing company charges $\$45$ for 100 flyers and $\$75$ for 200 flyers. Assuming a linear relationship, find the cost equation and predict the cost for 250 flyers.

step_by_step.explanation: Let x = number of flyers, y = cost. Points: $(100, 45)$ and $(200, 75)$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Two data points give the cost function; use it for predictions.

worked_examples.title: Population Growth
worked_examples.problem: A town's population was 12,000 in 2010 and 15,000 in 2020. Assuming linear growth, write the population equation and predict the population in 2030.

step_by_step.explanation: Let t = years since 2010, P = population. Points: $(0, 12000)$ and $(10, 15000)$

worked_examples.concept_applied: Two population points give growth rate and allow prediction.

sections.section_title: 5.3.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when writing equations from two points. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Subtracting in different order in numerator and denominator.
Trying to calculate slope for vertical or horizontal lines as if they were normal.
characteristics: Attempting to divide by zero for vertical lines
Not recognizing when slope is zero

image.alt: Vertical line with incorrect slope attempt
image.caption: Figure 5.3.33: Error - mishandling special cases.

examples.process: Error: For points (3,4) and (3,7), saying slope = 3/0 = 0
examples.explanation: Correct: slope undefined, line is vertical x = 3

classifications.value: Mistakes when subtracting fractions or combining terms.

examples.process: Error: For $(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{4})$ and $(\frac{3}{2}, \frac{7}{4})$, $m = \frac{7/4 - 3/4}{3/2 - 1/2} = \frac{1}{1} = 1$ (this is actually correct). Need better example.
examples.explanation: Example where error might occur: $(\frac{1}{3}, \frac{1}{2})$ and $(\frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{4})$

worked_examples.title: Correcting Two-Point Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student found the equation through $(1, 3)$ and $(4, 9)$ as $y = 2x + 1$. Is this correct? If not, find the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Student's answer is correct! Need an error example.
step_by_step.calculation: Let's create one: For points (1,4) and (3,10), student might get $y = 3x + 1$? Check: $m = (10-4)/(3-1) = 6/2 = 3$, using (1,4): $4 = 3(1)+b$ → $b=1$, so $y=3x+1$ is correct. Hmm.

worked_examples.final_answer: The student's equation is correct. To illustrate an error, consider points (2,5) and (5,14): correct slope = 3, correct equation $y=3x-1$. A common error might be using wrong point or arithmetic mistake.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always verify both slope and intercept calculations.

image.alt: Summary table of common two-point errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 5.3.36: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to write equations from various pairs of points.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Write the equation of the line through each pair of points:
1) $(2, 5)$ and $(4, 11)$
2) $(-3, 2)$ and $(1, -6)$
3) $(0, 4)$ and $(5, 2)$
4) $(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{3}{2})$ and $(\frac{5}{2}, \frac{7}{2})$
5) $(3, 4)$ and $(3, -2)$
6) $(2, 5)$ and $(7, 5)$
7) Real-world: A car travels 120 miles in 2 hours and 300 miles in 5 hours. Write distance-time equation and find speed.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice writing equations from various point pairs.

summary: Given two points $(x_1, y_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2)$, we can find the equation of the line through them in three steps: (1) Calculate the slope using $m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}$. (2) Use point-slope form $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$ with either point. (3) Simplify to slope-intercept form $y = mx + b$. Alternatively, after finding slope, substitute into $y = mx + b$ to solve for $b$ directly: $b = y_1 - m x_1$. Special cases occur when the points have the same y-coordinate (horizontal line $y = y_1$) or same x-coordinate (vertical line $x = x_1$). When points have fractional coordinates, careful fraction arithmetic is required. Real-world applications include finding relationships from two data points, allowing predictions through interpolation (between points) and extrapolation (beyond points). This method is fundamental for modeling linear relationships from experimental data, historical records, or any situation where two measurements are known.

review_questions_image.alt: Comprehensive summary: slope formula, point-slope method, direct b method, special cases, real-world applications
review_questions_image.caption: Figure 5.3.39: Given two points summary.
